Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Cued Recall: Theory and Data

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite the importance of memory to everyday functioning and the functioning of society, the basic processes underlying the healthy function of the human memory system are not yet fully understood. "Episodic memory" is the ability to remember the components of a particular event, such as the food one ate for lunch yesterday (in contrast to the "semantic memory" for the fact that lunch is defined as a meal eaten in the middle of the day). It can be difficult to remember the specific details of a single event especially when the same components appear in multiple different events (e.g., bread may appear in many different meals) and events often repeat (e.g., lunch is eaten everyday). The NSF-funded research project conducted by Dr. Amy Criss at Syracuse University aims to evaluate three critical components of memory: first, the properties that contribute to the ability of a cue to successfully elicit a memory, independent of the content of the memory; second, the nature of the content of the memory that is successfully retrieved and reported, independent of the cue; finally, how cues and content can interact so that a cue is particularly effective for particular content, but not for other content (for example, sometimes a smell serves as a cue to elicit a very strong memory for a particular life event, such as a high school dance). To study these components of episodic memory, Dr. Criss will create laboratory events to be remembered by adult participants. Later, memory for those events will be measured. This research will advance understanding of episodic memory by using behavioral measures of memory in adults and by building a computer model that mimics the human memory system.

This research will contribute to understanding the fundamental processes that underlie human episodic memory. Memory is the essence of a person. It dictates behavior, preferences, fears, and abilities. Everyday failures of memory are common and costs range from spending a few extra minutes searching for car keys to falsely incriminating an innocent person. Critical components of society rely on memory. The judicial system relies on testimony of memory for events as a primary basis for determining innocence or guilt. Educators judge mastery of knowledge based on the ability to remember key facts during an examination. This research has the potential to inform the criminal justice system and educational testing on the properties of effective memory cues and also has the potential to contribute to treatments of memory disorders. This project also aims to train graduate and undergraduate students to be critical and effective consumers of science both inside and outside of the laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Memory is an essential function for success in daily life. Often memories involve binding together two individual elements (for example a person’s name and face) and being able to remember one of those elements (the name) when presented with the other as a cue (the face). What makes a cue one that helps people retrieve a specific memory and what makes a specific memory easy or difficult to remember? What facilitates forming an association between items, especially when a given element might co-occur with other items (for example, multiple people have the same name). This research project has sought to answer these questions by conducting experiments and by developing a computational model that remembers and forgets in the same way that people do. A model is a useful tool because we can run studies on the model to predict what will happen in a novel situation. We can also disable or change parts of the model to predict how people might remember or forget information if the memory system is damaged.

We discovered that specific properties of items such as how often they occur in the environment, how atypical they are in the natural world, and whether they occur in a specific or diverse contexts in the world affects their ability to be associated with other items and thus their memorability. We also discovered that the conditions in which a memory is retrieved will affect momentary memory decisions. That is, a person might fail to remember an item not because it is lost from memory but because of the specific conditions under which they are trying to remember. For example, accuracy is worse when an item is cued at the end of several successive retrievals of elements of the same event. Another important finding of this research is that elements might be bound together to form an association in memory that is unique to the combination of the two elements. This unitization protects the memory from forgetting by making it different from other memories that might share one of the elements.

As a whole, this research has improved understanding of associative memory and how elements of an event are represented in memory. This has potential implications in any arena where human memory is important such as educational testing, workforce training, criminal justice, and medicine.

Beyond the implications of the research, this project has provided opportunities for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral fellows, especially those from underrepresented groups in STEM, to participate in research and improve their computational, writing, and presentation skills. Training in addition to extensive mentoring has helped to expand the scientific workforce.

Educational materials were developed and widely shared in the course of this research project. They focus on testing hypothesis and theories to evaluate and understand data. These materials have helped hundreds of students across the country to become more informed consumers of science.
